docs.lead_paragraph: Now that the General Assembly session is at the halfway mark, one Democratic legislator summed up its biggest challenge this way: ''Who is going to be the grownup?'' In other words, with a budget surplus and two huge proposals dominating the agenda, what's a responsible legislator to do?
docs.abstract: Editorial supports Connecticut Gov M Jodi Rell's proposal to raise income tax to give millions more to education, but says opponents have legitimate concerns that must be addressed
docs.snippet: With a budget surplus and two huge proposals dominating the Assembly’s agenda, what’s a responsible legislator to do?
docs.section_name: Health; New York and Region; Opinion

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Medicaid Documentation Mess'' (editorial, March 19): You describe vividly our government's ploy to deprive needy Americans of survival resources. But these paperwork barriers to health care for newborn American citizens are just one example of a broad campaign to use bureaucratic means to deny poor Americans the support that is rightfully theirs.
docs.abstract: Letter from Robert M Hayes, president of Medicare Rights Center, says complex application processes disentitles poor from benefits like Medicaid (March 19 editorial)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:      Re ''The Medicaid Documentation Mess'' (editorial, March 19):      You describe vividly our government's ploy to deprive needy Americans of survival resources. But these paperwork barriers to health care for newborn American...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Facing Life With a Lethal Gene'' (front page, March 18), about Katharine Moser, a 25-year-old woman who learned two years ago that she carries the gene for Huntington's disease, which usually strikes in middle age: What a tremendous example and inspiration Ms. Moser is. She is facing her future with a huge amount of courage and determination and doing the best she can with what life has handed her.
docs.abstract: Five letters respond to March 18 article about genetic testing for Huntington's disease; Simone A Wegge says young woman in article who tested positive for gene is inspiration; Dr Deborah C Peel, chairwoman of Patient Privacy Rights, says genetic records could be used for discrimination; June Walker calls for legislation protecting genetic privacy; Anne Roth-Reinhardt says genetic testing shows psychological burden of genetic knowledge; David N Regen says he does not trust that genetic records will be privacy protected; drawing
